Th© uxl decided not to join the other two unions in last week's
strike* Di Vittorio and Company can he depended on to use this abstention
effectively to point out to workers that the OIL puts its dislike of col¬
laboration with the CGIL ahead of its devotion to their interests* At the
moment, of course, Di Vittorio and the Communists are hailing the unity
between themselves and the CISL. They are putting up posters, saying that
this teamwork demonstrates what can be accomplished if the unions will only
stick together. It's propaganda for what you might call a Popular Front on
the labor union level to go along with the Communist-Left Socialist bids
for a Popular Front on the strictly political level*
There is no sure way to measure this, but some observers are con¬
vinced that Pastore's CISL has lost ground in recent weeks and months. They
cite as factors in such losses three things * the Christian Democratic
party's losses in the national elections last June; the dilemma in which
Pastor© found himself in the recent strike of workers against the Christian
Democratic government! and, finally, the attacks that have been made on him
for teaming up with the Communists*
In summary, the effort by Italian democrats to bring about de¬
fections from Communist leadership on both the political and labor union
level seem at the moment to be making little progress. There is some
evidence that the defections, in fact, are going in the other direction.
Graham Hovey, signing another radio Letter from Italy. This
program was recorded in the Home studios of Radio I tall ana for the National
